hints.content:
An $\blueE{\text{even}}$ number is a number that can be split into $2$ equal groups.

We find $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers by making sure every object in the group has a pair.

![2 rows of cookies. Row 1 has 3 cookies. Row 2 has 3 cookies. A vertical dotted line divides the cookies into 3 columns so there are 3 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d50cd961bb1ee962eb60cc708a5e737e9d4486c)

Examples of $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers are $\blueE2, \blueE4,\blueE6, \blueE8, \blueE{10},  . .  .$

An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

We find $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers by trying to pair objects and finding there is **not** always a pair.

![2 columns of cookies. Column 1 has 3 cookies. Column 2 has 2 cookies. A horizontal dotted line divides the cookies into 3 rows so there are 2 pairs with 1 extra cookie.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/10c3af09ebfcd0c6d05b4edd219f33894cc4d8b9)

Examples of $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers are $\maroonD1, \maroonD3, \maroonD5, \maroonD7, \maroonD9, . . . $

In this image, there are $\maroonD9$ cheese triangles.

![2 columns of cheese triangles. Column 1 has 5 cheese triangles. Column 2 has 4 cheese triangles. A horizontal dotted line divides the cheese triangles into 5 rows so there are 4 pairs with 1 extra cheese triangle.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f43b4da0a1cdc117dcb33e878cb9411e87c07af7)

Each cheese triangle does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of cheese triangles.

In this image, there are $\maroonD{11}$ cheese triangles.

![2 rows of cheese triangles. Row 1 has 5 cheese triangles. Row 2 has 6 cheese triangles. A vertical dotted line divides the cheese triangles into 6 columns so there are 5 pairs with 1 extra cheese triangle.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/27b48a7fdf2c958a0d8d5a83a4a7a92b3dd0f75a)

Each cheese triangle does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of cheese triangles.

In this image, there are $\blueE{10}$ cheese triangles.

![2 rows of cheese triangles. Row 1 has 5 cheese triangles. Row 2 has 5 cheese triangles. A vertical dotted line divides the cheese triangles into 5 columns so there are 5 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/6c05692f73bd892e6f6cf75d47f8b461c2264f3d)

Each cheese triangle has a pair, so there are an even number of cheese triangles.

This image shows an even number of cheese triangles:

![2 rows of cheese triangles. Row 1 has 5 cheese triangles. Row 2 has 5 cheese triangles.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5cad2b898ca9d8342467ea6144f3941b6c6d0de1)

question.content:
**Which image shows an even number of cheese triangles?**

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: ![2 rows of cheese triangles. Row 1 has 5 cheese triangles. Row 2 has 6 cheese triangles.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9eada5a8349ac4cb0f7a3ec4a7436caa87871d24)
![2 columns of cheese triangles. Column 1 has 5 cheese triangles. Column 2 has 4 cheese triangles.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5082127df826530adec93509402742eaecb98c14)
![2 rows of cheese triangles. Row 1 has 5 cheese triangles. Row 2 has 5 cheese triangles.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5cad2b898ca9d8342467ea6144f3941b6c6d0de1)
